25:T7c0,<entryFree id="n28388" key="عَدَوِيَّةٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عَدَوِيَّةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> The <hi rend="ital">herbage of the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">صَيْف</foreign> [q. v., here app. meaning <hi rend="ital">spring</hi>], <hi rend="ital">after the departure of the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">رَبِيع</foreign> [q. v., here app. meaning <hi rend="ital">winter</hi>]: (S, K:) it is applied to the <hi rend="ital">young trees which then become green and are depastured by the camels:</hi> (S:) or, as some say, the [<hi rend="ital">plants,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">herbage, called</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">رَبْل</foreign> [q. v.]. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And The <hi rend="ital">young ones of sheep</hi> or <hi rend="ital">goats.</hi> (K.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">Female infants</hi> [<hi rend="ital">of the age</hi>] <hi rend="ital">of forty days;</hi> (K, TA; [in the CK, <foreign lang="ar">نَبات</foreign> is erroneously put for <foreign lang="ar">بَنَات</foreign>;]) <hi rend="ital">but when their</hi> [<hi rend="ital">hair termed</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">عَقِيقَة</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">has been cut off, this appel-lation is no longer applied to them:</hi> so says Lth; but Az pronounces him to have erred: (TA:) or it is with <foreign lang="ar">غ</foreign> (K, TA) and <foreign lang="ar">ذ</foreign>, both dotted, or only the former of them dotted, and one of them is called <foreign lang="ar">غَدِىٌّ</foreign> [or <foreign lang="ar">غَدَوِىٌّ</foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar">غَذِىٌّ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">غَذَوِىٌّ</foreign>]: thus in the M, and thus accord. to Az. (TA.)    </entryFree>26:T42c1,<entryFree id="n28369" key="عَدَاهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>1</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عَدَاهُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (Mgh, K,) first pers. <foreign lang="ar">عَدَوْتُهُ</foreign>, (Msb,) aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَعْدُو</foreign>, (Mgh, Msb,) [inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَدْوٌ</foreign>,] <hi rend="ital">He passed from it,</hi> (Mgh, Msb, K,) namely, a thing, or an affair, (K,) to another, (Mgh, Msb,) <hi rend="ital">and left it;</hi> (K;) and <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا عَنْهُ</foreign> signifies the same; (K;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-1" target="تعدّاه" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>; (S, * K;) and in like manner one says,   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-2" target="عَدَّيْتُهُ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَعْدِيَةٌ</foreign>; (Msb;) [but I do not find this elsewhere, and think that correctly one should say, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-3" target="عَدَّيْتُ" n="3" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>عَنْهُ</foreign>; agreeably with what here follows:] the saying <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-4" target="عَدِّ" n="4" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>عَنْ هٰذَا</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">Leave thou this,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">turn from it to another;</hi> and is app. from the phrase <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-5" target="عَدِّ" n="5" type="8" subtype="FSOTF" lang="ar"/>هَمَّكَ إِلَى غَيْرِهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Turn thy anxiety to other than him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it</hi>]; the objective complement being altogether left out, so that the verb becomes as though it were intrans.; and there are many instances similar to this in the language: (Har p. 478:) one says, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-6" target="عَدَّيْتُ" n="6" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>عَنِّى الهَمَّ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">I turned away from me anxiety:</hi> and [hence] you say to him who has pursued you, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-7" target="عَدِّ" n="7" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>عَنِّى إِلَى غَيْرِى</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">Turn thou</hi> the beast upon which thou art riding <hi rend="ital">towards other than me:</hi> (TA:) and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-8" target="عَدِّ" n="8" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>عَمَّا تَرَى</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">Turn thou</hi> thine eye <hi rend="ital">from what thou seest.</hi> (S.) [See an ex. of the first of these verbs in the Ham p. 125.] One says also, <foreign lang="ar">عَدَاهُ الأَمْرُ</foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-9" target="تعدّاهُ" n="9" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The thing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">affair, passed from him.</hi> (TA. [See an ex. in the first paragraph of art. <foreign lang="ar">عدم</foreign>.]) And the Arabs say, <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّ الجَرَبَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">لَيَعْدُو</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">Verily the mange,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scab, passes</hi> from him that has it to him that is near to him so that the latter becomes mangy, or scabby. (Msb.) And <foreign lang="ar">مَا عَدَا فُلَانٌ أَنْ صَنَعَ</foreign> [app. meaning <hi rend="ital">Such a one did not leave,</hi> or, accord. to an explanation of the verb in a similar phrase in Har p. 333, <hi rend="ital">did not delay, his doing</hi> such a thing]. (S.) Accord. to Er-Rághib, <foreign lang="ar">العَدْوُ</foreign> primarily signifies <hi rend="ital">Transition;</hi> [whence what here precedes;] or <hi rend="ital">the going,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">passing, beyond,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the exceeding,</hi> a limit, or the usual limit: and <hi rend="ital">incompatibility to coalesce.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And [hence,] <foreign lang="ar">عَدَاهُ</foreign>, aor. as above, [inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَدْوٌ</foreign>,] <hi rend="ital">He went,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">passed, beyond it; exceeded it;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">transgressed it.</hi> (S, TA. *) So in the saying <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا طَوْرَهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He went,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">passed, beyond his proper limit; exceeded it;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">transgressed it</hi>]: and in like manner, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-10" target="تعدّى" n="10" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>الحَقَّ</foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-11" target="اعتداهُ" n="11" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signify <hi rend="ital">He went,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">passed, beyond,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">what was true,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">right;</hi> and so <foreign lang="ar">عَنِ الحَقِّ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">فَوْقَ الحَقِّ</foreign>. (TA.) <foreign lang="ar">أَمَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا مَنْ بَدَا</foreign>, a saying in which the vulgar erroneously omit the interrogative <foreign lang="ar">أ</foreign>, means <hi rend="ital">Does not he transgress that which is right who begins</hi> by acting injuriously? (TA.) And it is said <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">القَارِصُ فَحَرَزَ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">What was biting to the tongue attained to an excessive degree, so that it became acid:</hi> meaning that the affair, or case, became distressing. (S in art. <foreign lang="ar">قرص</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا عَلَيْهِ</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَدْوٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عَدَآءٌ</foreign> (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and <foreign lang="ar">عُدُوٌّ</foreign> (S, Msb, K) and <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوَانٌ</foreign> (ISd, Msb, K) and <foreign lang="ar">عِدْوَانٌ</foreign> (ISd, K) and <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوَى</foreign>; (K;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-12" target="تعدّى" n="12" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-13" target="اعتدى" n="13" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>; (S, Msb, K;) <hi rend="ital">He acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyrannically, against him;</hi> (S, Msb, K;) and <hi rend="ital">transgressed against him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">exceeded the proper limit against him:</hi> (S, Msb:) [and <hi rend="ital">he acted aggressively against him;</hi> agreeably with an explanation of the inf. n. of the last of these verbs in what follows: (see an ex. in a verse cited voce <foreign lang="ar">رِيحٌ</foreign>:)] or <hi rend="ital">he acted with excessive wrongfulness,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">against him:</hi> (Mgh:) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-14" target="اعدى" n="14" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies the same as the other verbs here mentioned; (K, TA;) whence (TA) one says, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-15" target="أَعْدَيْتَ" n="15" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>فِى مَنْطِقِكَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Thou hast deviated from that which is right in thy speech:</hi> (S, TA:)   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-16" target="الاِعْتِدَآءُ" n="16" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> is <hi rend="ital">the exceeding what is right;</hi> and it is sometimes <hi rend="ital">in the way of aggression;</hi> and sometimes <hi rend="ital">in the way of requital;</hi> and instances of the usage of its verb in both of these manners occur in the Kur ii. 190: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the first and third of the inf. ns. of <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا</foreign>, mentioned above, occur in the Kur vi. 108 accord. to different readings: (S, TA:) and [it is said that] <foreign lang="ar">العُدْوَانُ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">sheer,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">unmixed, wrongful</hi> or <hi rend="ital">unjust</hi> or <hi rend="ital">injurious</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyrannical conduct:</hi> (S:) or, as some say, <hi rend="ital">the worst of</hi> [<hi rend="ital">such conduct,</hi> i. e., <hi rend="ital">of</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">الاِعْتِدَآء</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">in strength,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">deed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">state</hi> or <hi rend="ital">condition.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَيْهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He acted corruptly towards him.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">عُدِىَ عَلَيْهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He had his property stolen, and was wronged.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا عَلَى القُمَاشِ</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَدَآءٌ</foreign> [said in the TA to be like <foreign lang="ar">سَحَابٌ</foreign>, but in the CK <foreign lang="ar">عَدًا</foreign>,] and <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوَانٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عَدَوَانٌ</foreign>, (K, TA,) but in the M written with damm and fet-h [i. e. <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوَان</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عَدْوَان</foreign>], (TA,) said of a thief, <hi rend="ital">He stole the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">قماش</foreign> [meaning <hi rend="ital">goods,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">utensils and furniture</hi>]. (K, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا فِى ظَهْرِهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He stole what was behind him:</hi> (A in art. <foreign lang="ar">ظهر</foreign>:) [or <hi rend="ital">he acted wrongfully in respect of what was behind him:</hi> for] <foreign lang="ar">لِصٌّ عَادِى ظَهْرٍ</foreign> is expl. by the words <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا فِى ظَهْرٍ فَسَرَقَهُ</foreign> [so that it app. means <hi rend="ital">A thief who has acted wrongfully in respect of what was behind one, and stolen it</hi>]. (O and K in that art.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا عَلَيْهِ</foreign>, (K, TA,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَدْوٌ</foreign>, (TA,) signifies also <hi rend="ital">He leaped upon him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it.</hi> (K, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا</foreign>, (K,) or <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا فِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَشْيِهِ</foreign>, (Msb,) aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَعْدُو</foreign>, (Msb, K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَدْوٌ</foreign> (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and <foreign lang="ar">عَدًا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عُدُوٌّ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عَدَوَانٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">تَعْدَآءٌ</foreign>, (K,) signifies <foreign lang="ar">أَحْضَرَ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">He ran;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">rose in his running</hi>]; (S, * K, TA;) said of a man and of a horse: (TA:) or <hi rend="ital">he went a pace nearly the same as that termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">هَرْوَلَةٌ</foreign>, (Msb, TA,) <hi rend="ital">not so quick,</hi> (TA,) or <hi rend="ital">which is not so quick,</hi> (Msb,) <hi rend="ital">as that termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">جَرْىٌ</foreign>: (Msb, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">he went a pace less quick than</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">شَدٌّ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">and more so than</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَشْىٌ</foreign>: (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">سعى</foreign>:) or [<hi rend="ital">he went quickly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">swiftly;</hi> for] <foreign lang="ar">العَدْوُ</foreign> signifies <foreign lang="ar">السُّرْعَةُ</foreign>: (Mgh:) [or rather <hi rend="ital">he ran,</hi> whether <hi rend="ital">gently</hi> or <hi rend="ital">moderately</hi> or <hi rend="ital">vehemently:</hi> that it often signifies <hi rend="ital">he ran vehemently</hi> is shown by the prov. <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-17" target="أَعْدَى" n="17" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n28399"/>مِنْ سُلَيْكٍ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">More vehement in running than Suleyk,</hi> who is said to have outstripped fleet horses; and by numerous exs.:] and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-18" target="عّى" n="18" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies the same as <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا</foreign>, denoting a quick pace. (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">هبص</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="8">-b8-</sense>  And [hence, perhaps,] <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا المَآءُ</foreign>, aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَعْدُو</foreign>, <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">The water ran.</hi> (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَدَاهُ عَنِ الأَمْرِ</foreign>, (S, K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عَدْوٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوَانٌ</foreign>; as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28369-19" target="عدّاهُ" n="19" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>; (K;) signifies <hi rend="ital">He,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, diverted him;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">turned him away,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">back;</hi> (S, K;) and <hi rend="ital">occupied him so as to divert him;</hi> (K;) <hi rend="ital">from the thing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">affair.</hi> (S, K.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">عَدَتْ عَوَادٍ</foreign>. (S, TA.                   <foreign lang="ar">شَرٌّ</foreign> means <foreign lang="ar">بَلَغَنِى</foreign> [i. e., app., <hi rend="ital">Evil,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mischief, reached me from him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it</hi>]. (TA. [See a signi- <pb n="1978"/> fication of 4.])       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَدِيتُ لَهُ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">I hated him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it.</hi> (ISd, K.)       <sense type="A" n="4">-A4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا</foreign> is also a verb by which one makes an exception, with <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign> [preceding it] and without <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign>: (S, K:) you say, <foreign lang="ar">جَآءَنِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">القَوْمُ مَا عَدَا زَيْدًا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The people,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">party, came to me, except Zeyd</hi>]; and <foreign lang="ar">جَاؤُونِى عَدَا زَيْدًا</foreign> [which means the like]; putting what follows it in the accus. case; the agent being implied in it: (S: [see this expl. in what has been said of <foreign lang="ar">خَلَا</foreign> as used in the same manner:]) accord. to MF, it is a verb when what follows it is put in the accus. case; and when what follows it is put in the gen. case, it is a particle, by common consent: (TA: [and the like is said in the Mughnee; i. e., that it is similar to <foreign lang="ar">خَلَا</foreign> in respect of the explanations there given of the different usages of this latter; but that Sb did not know it to have been used otherwise than as having the quality of a verb:]) one says, <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُهُمْ عَدَا أَخَاكَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">مَا عَدَاهُ</foreign>, meaning <foreign lang="ar">مَا خَلَا</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">I saw them, except thy brother</hi>]: and sometimes it governs the gen. case without <foreign lang="ar">ما</foreign>: thus in the M: Az says, [as though regarding it as only a particle,] when you suppress [<foreign lang="ar">ما</foreign>], you make it to govern the accus. case as meaning <foreign lang="ar">إِلَّا</foreign> and you make it to govern the gen. case as meaning <foreign lang="ar">سِوَى</foreign>.                   </form>, (K, TA,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">مُعَادَاةٌ</foreign>, (S, K, TA,) [<hi rend="ital">He treated him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">regarded him, with enmity,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hostility:</hi>] the verb in this phrase is that of which the epithet is <foreign lang="ar">عَدُوٌّ</foreign>, and the subst. is <foreign lang="ar">عَدَاوَةٌ</foreign>. (K, TA.) [It is perhaps from one of the three phrases next following].          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عادى الشَّىْءَ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">He was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aloof, from the thing;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he made the thing to be,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">become, distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aloof;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">بَاعَدَهُ</foreign>. (TA.) And you say, <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ لَا يُعَادِينِى وَلَا يُوَادِينِى</foreign>, meaning <foreign lang="ar">لَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">يُجَافِينِى وَلَا يُوَاتِينِى</foreign> [app. <hi rend="ital">Such a one will not make me to be,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">become, remote,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aloof, from him, nor will he comply with me:</hi> but <foreign lang="ar">لَا يُوَادِينِى</foreign> properly signifies <hi rend="ital">he will not take from me the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">دِيَة</foreign>, or <hi rend="ital">bloodwit</hi>]. (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">عَادِ رِجْلَكَ عَنِ</foreign>

                  <hi rend="ital">Draw away thy leg,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">foot, from the ground.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">عَادَى الأَدَاةَ عَنِ البَعِيرِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He raised</hi> [<hi rend="ital">partially</hi>] <hi rend="ital">the furniture</hi> (<hi rend="ital">consisting of the saddle and saddle-cloth</hi>) <hi rend="ital">from contact with the camel</hi> [<hi rend="ital">so as to render it bearable by him</hi>].                   <hi rend="ital">He took</hi> [<hi rend="ital">somewhat</hi>] <hi rend="ital">from his hair:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he raised it,</hi> (K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">in washing it:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he neglected it, and did not oil it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">anoint it:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he subjected it time after time to the purification termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">وُضُوع</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">and to washing.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عادى الوِسَادَةَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He folded the pillow.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عادى القِدْرَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He lowered one of the three stones upon which the cooking-pot rested, in order that it</hi> (the pot) <hi rend="ital">might incline upon the fire.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عادى بَيْنَ الصَّيْدَينِ</foreign>, (S, * K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">عِدَآءٌ</foreign> (S, K) and <foreign lang="ar">مُعَادَاةٌ</foreign>, (K,) <hi rend="ital">He made a succession, of one to the other, between the two animals of the chase,</hi> (S, K,) <hi rend="ital">by throwing down one of them immediately after the other,</hi> (S,) <hi rend="ital">in one</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">طَلَق</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">heat</hi>]. (S, K.) Imra-el-Keys says, [describing a horse,] <quote>

                        <foreign lang="ar">فَعَادَى عِدَآءً بَيْنَ ثَوْرٍ وَنَعْجَةٍ</foreign>
                     </L>

                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">And he made a succession, of one to the other, between a wild bull and a wild cow, by running down one after the other in a single heat, overtaking uninterruptedly, and not breaking out with water</hi> (i. e. <hi rend="ital">sweat</hi>) <hi rend="ital">so as to become suffused</hi> therewith]. (S. [See EM p. 49.]) In like manner also <foreign lang="ar">المُعَادَاةُ بَيْنَ رَجُلَيْنِ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">The piercing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thrusting, two men, one after the other, uninterruptedly.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">عَادَيْتُهُ</foreign> [sometimes] signifies <hi rend="ital">I vied,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">contended, with him in running; i. q.</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">حَاضَرْتُهُ</foreign>, from <foreign lang="ar">الحُضْرُ</foreign>. (A in art. <foreign lang="ar">حضر</foreign>.)    </entryFree>29:T11f3,<entryFree id="n28372" key="اعدى الأَمْرَ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>4</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">اعدى الأَمْرَ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He passed from,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">beyond, another, to the thing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">affair:</hi> so in the K. (TA.) But in the M it is said, <foreign lang="ar">اعداهُ الدَّآءُ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">The disease passed from another to him.</hi> (TA.) And one says <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَى فُلَانٌ فُلَانًا مِنْ خُلُقِهِ</foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ عِلَّةٍ بِهِ</foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar">جَرَبٍ</foreign>, (S, TA,) i. e. <hi rend="ital">Such a one made somewhat of his natural disposition,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">of a disease,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">malady, that was in him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">of mange,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scab, to pass</hi> [<hi rend="ital">from him</hi>] <hi rend="ital">to such a one;</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">infected him therewith;</hi> (see two exs., in a verse and a hemistich, cited in the first paragraph of art. <foreign lang="ar">جنى</foreign>;)] and <foreign lang="ar">اعداهُ بِهِ</foreign> signifies the same: and <foreign lang="ar">اعدى صَاحِبَهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He made his companion to acquire the like of what was in him.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">يُعْدِى</foreign> is said of the mange, or scab, &amp;c., meaning <hi rend="ital">It passes from him that has it to another;</hi> (S, K;) and in like manner one says of a disease,   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28372-1" target="يتعدّى" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>: (Nh, TA:) but it is said in an explanation of a trad., <foreign lang="ar">لَا يُعْدِى شَىْءٌ شَيْئًا</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">A thing</hi> (meaning disease) <hi rend="ital">does not pass</hi> by its own agency <hi rend="ital">to a thing</hi>]. (S, TA.) [Therefore] one says, of the mange, or scab, [or the like,] <foreign lang="ar">اعداهُ ٱللّٰهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">God made it to pass from him that had it to one that was near to him, so that he became affected therewith.</hi> (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  One says also, of a man, <foreign lang="ar">قَدْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَى النَّاسَ بِشَرٍّ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He has made evil,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mischief, to cleave to men.</hi> (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  See also 1, near the middle, in two places.       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">اعداهُ عَلَيْهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He aided,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">assisted, him,</hi> (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) <hi rend="ital">and strengthened him,</hi> (K,) <hi rend="ital">against him;</hi> (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) <hi rend="ital">and avenged him of him;</hi> (S, Msb;) namely, one who had wronged him. (S, Mgh, Msb.) And <foreign lang="ar">اعداهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He</hi> (a judge) <hi rend="ital">heard his accusation against another, and commanded to bring his adversary.</hi> (Mgh.)       <sense type="A" n="4">-A4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">اعداهُ</foreign>, (S, Msb, K, TA,) namely, a horse, (S, TA,) and also a man, (TA,) [<hi rend="ital">He made him to run,</hi> whether <hi rend="ital">gently</hi> or <hi rend="ital">moderately</hi> or <hi rend="ital">vehemently:</hi> or, as sometimes used,] <hi rend="ital">he made him,</hi> (K, TA,) or <hi rend="ital">desired him,</hi> (S,) <hi rend="ital">to go the pace termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">حُضْر</foreign>: (S, K, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">he made him to go a pace nearly the same as that termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">هَرْوَلَة</foreign>, (Msb, TA,) <hi rend="ital">not so quick,</hi> (TA,) or <hi rend="ital">which is not so quick,</hi> (Msb,) <hi rend="ital">as that termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">جَرْى</foreign>: (Msb, TA: [see 1, latter half:]) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28372-2" target="استعداهُ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies the same. (S.)    </entryFree>2a:T5fd,<entryFree id="n28372-4" key="تَعَدَّوَ">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>5</itype>        
                     <orth lang="ar">تَعَدَّوَ</orth>
                  </form> see 1, first quarter, in two places: and see 4.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Hence <foreign lang="ar">تعدّى</foreign> said of a verb, <hi rend="ital">It was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, transitive.</hi>]          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">تعدّى الحَقَّ</foreign>: and <foreign lang="ar">تعدّى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَيْهِ</foreign>: see 1, second quarter, in two places.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">تَعَدَّوْا</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">They found milk,</hi> (K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">which they drank,</hi> (TA,) <hi rend="ital">and it rendered them in no need of wine:</hi> (K, TA:) so in the copies of the K; but correctly, <hi rend="ital">of flesh-meat,</hi> as in the M.                   <hi rend="ital">Mange,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scab,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">other disease, that passes,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">is transitive, from one to another;</hi> (S, K, TA;) <hi rend="ital">a transitive disease;</hi> and such is said to be the <foreign lang="ar">جَرَب</foreign>, and the <foreign lang="ar">بَرَص</foreign>, and the <foreign lang="ar">رَمَد</foreign>, and the <foreign lang="ar">حَصْبَة</foreign>, and the <foreign lang="ar">جُذَام</foreign>, and the <foreign lang="ar">وَبَآء</foreign>, and the <foreign lang="ar">جُدَرِىّ</foreign>.                   <foreign lang="ar">فَإِنَّ بِهِ عَدْوَى</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Do not thou bring him near to him, for in him is a disease such as the mange,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scab, that is transitive from one to another.</hi> (TK.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And The <hi rend="ital">transition of the mange,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scab,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">other disease, from him that has it to another:</hi> (S, K, TA, TK:) the subst. from <foreign lang="ar">يَعْدُو</foreign> said of the mange, or scab, expl. above, as meaning “ it passes ” &amp;c. (Msb. [See 1, first quarter.]) It is said in a trad., <foreign lang="ar">لَا عَدْوَى</foreign>, i. e. <foreign lang="ar">لَا يُعْدِى شَىْءٌ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">شَيْئًا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">A thing</hi> (meaning disease) <hi rend="ital">does not pass</hi> by its own agency <hi rend="ital">to a thing</hi>]; (S;) or [lit.] <hi rend="ital">there is no transition of the mange,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scab,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">other disease, from him that has it to another.</hi> (TK.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">i. q.</hi>

      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28385-3" target="عِدًى" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n28380"/></foreign>, (Ham p. 377,) [or particularly] of a house, or an abode, or a dwelling. (S, TA.) [Hence,] one says, <foreign lang="ar">طَالَتْ عُدَوَاؤُهُمْ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Their distance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remoteness, one from another,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">their separation, was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, long.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also (i. e. the first and ↓ second and ↓ third words) <hi rend="ital">Occupation,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">business, that turns one away,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">back, from a thing:</hi> (K, TA:) or <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوَآءُ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">a custom,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">habit, of occupation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">business:</hi> (TA:) and <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوَآءُ الشُّغْلِ</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the hindrances,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">impediments, of occupation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">business:</hi> (S, TA:) and one says, <foreign lang="ar">جِئْتَنِى وَأَنَا فِى عُدَوَآءَ عَنْكَ</foreign> i. e. [<hi rend="ital">Thou camest to me when I was engaged</hi>] <hi rend="ital">in an occupation that diverted</hi> [me <hi rend="ital">from thee</hi>]: (so in one of my copies of the S:) the pl. of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28385-4" target="عَادِيَةٌ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n28398"/></foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">عَوَادٍ</foreign>: (TA:) <foreign lang="ar">عَوَادِى الدَّهْرِ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">the accidents,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">casualties, of time</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fortune, that divert</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">intervene as obstacles</hi>] <hi rend="ital">by occupying</hi> or <hi rend="ital">busying:</hi> (S:) and you say, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28385-5" target="عَدَتْ" n="5" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>عَوَادِ</foreign>, [lit.] meaning <hi rend="ital">Things,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">events, turning away,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">back, turned,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">have turned, away,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">back;</hi> [but this phrase, when followed by <foreign lang="ar">دُونَ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign>, I would rather render, simply, <hi rend="ital">obstacles occurred,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">have occurred;</hi>] (S, TA;) thus in the latter of two verses cited voce <foreign lang="ar">حَبَّ</foreign>. (S.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوَآءُ الدَّهْرِ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">The shifting,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">varying, of time</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fortune.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوَآءُ الشَّوْقِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">What has severely affected, distressed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">afflicted, its sufferer, of the yearning,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">longing, of the soul,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">of longing desire.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوَآءُ</foreign> signifies also <hi rend="ital">A</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَرْكَب</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">beast,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">saddle,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing on which one rides,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">that is not easy:</hi> (K:) or, accord. to As, <hi rend="ital">a place where he who sits thereon is not in a state of ease:</hi> and one says, <foreign lang="ar">جِئْتُ عَلَى مَرْكَبٍ ذِى عُدَوَآءَ</foreign> i. e. [<hi rend="ital">I came upon a beast,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">saddle,</hi> &amp;c.,] <hi rend="ital">that was not easy:</hi> (S:) and <foreign lang="ar">جِئْتُكَ عَلَى فَرَسٍ ذِى عُدَوَآءَ</foreign>, the last word imperfectly decl., i. e. [<hi rend="ital">I came to thee upon a horse</hi>] <hi rend="ital">that was not easy:</hi> (TA:) and <foreign lang="ar">جَلَسَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَى عُدَوَآءَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He sat upon an uneven thing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">place;</hi> (M, TA;) the last word imperfectly decl., as is said by ISd. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">Dry, hard, land;</hi> (K, TA;) <hi rend="ital">sometimes occurring in a well when it is dug; and sometimes it is stone, from which the digger turns aside:</hi> and one says, <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ ذَاتُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوَآءَ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">land that is not even,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">plain; not easy to walk</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ride</hi> or <hi rend="ital">lie upon:</hi> or, as some say, it means <hi rend="ital">a rough, rugged, place:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an elevated place upon which the camel lies down and then reclines thereon upon his side, having by his side a depressed place, which causes him to tend downwards, in consequence whereof he becomes in</hi> 
                  <pb n="1980"/> 
                  <hi rend="ital">the state termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تَوَهُّنٌ</foreign>, [<hi rend="ital">weak,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">languid, and unable to rise,</hi>] i. e. <hi rend="ital">in the condition of extending his body towards the low place while his legs are upon the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوَآء</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">which is the elevated, so that he is unable to rise, and dies.</hi> (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  And [it is said that] <foreign lang="ar">العُدَوَآءُ</foreign> also signifies <foreign lang="ar">اناخة قليلة</foreign> [app. <foreign lang="ar">إِنَاخَةٌ قَلِيلَةٌ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">A little,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">brief, making</hi> of a camel <hi rend="ital">to lie down upon the breast,</hi> as is done on the occasions of mounting and dismounting &amp;c.]. (TA.)    </entryFree>33:T95b,<entryFree id="n28386" key="عُدْوِىٌّ" type="main">

                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> and <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوِىٌّ</foreign> [are rel. ns. of which only the fem. forms are mentioned, in what here follows]. <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوِيَّةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوِيَّةٌ</foreign> are rel. ns. of <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوَةٌ</foreign> as meaning “ the kind of plants, or herbage, termed <foreign lang="ar">خُلَّة</foreign>, ” the former reg. and the latter irreg.; and <foreign lang="ar">عَوَادٍ</foreign> [pl. of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28386-1" target="عَادٍ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n28397"/></foreign> or of <foreign lang="ar">عَادِيَةٌ</foreign>] is a possessive epithet [from the same], without the relative <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign>: [all are app. applied to camels, as meaning <hi rend="ital">Having for their pasture the plants,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">herbage, called</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوَة</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">above mentioned:</hi> but it is immediately added,] and <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوِيَّةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوِيَّةٌ</foreign> applied to camels signify <hi rend="ital">that pasture upon the</hi> [<hi rend="ital">plants called</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">حَمْض</foreign>: (TA:) and

                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عَدُوٌّ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">And enemy, contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">وَلِىٌّ</foreign>, (S,) or <hi rend="ital">of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">صَدِيقٌ</foreign>, (K,) or <hi rend="ital">of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">صَدِيقٌ مُوَالٍ</foreign>; (Msb;) an epithet, but resembling a subst.: (S:) [and (like our word “ enemy ” in military parlance) <hi rend="ital">a hostile party:</hi> for] it is used alike as sing. and pl. and masc. and fem.; (Msb, K;) as is said in the “ Muk- tasar el-' Eyn: ” (Msb:) but sometimes it is dualized and pluralized and feminized: (K:) the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَآءٌ</foreign>; (S, Msb, K;) and the pl. of <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَآءٌ</foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">أَعَادٍ</foreign>; (Msb, K; *) and <foreign lang="ar">عِدًى</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عُدًى</foreign> are also pls. of <foreign lang="ar">عَدُوٌّ</foreign>; (S, Msb, K; [each improperly termed in the K <foreign lang="ar">اِسْمُ جَمْعٍ</foreign>; for <foreign lang="ar">فِعَلٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">فُعَلٌ</foreign> are measures of pls., not of quasi-pl. ns.;]) the former said by ISk to be the only pl. of this measure among epithets; (S, Msb; *) and <foreign lang="ar">عُدَاةٌ</foreign>, with damm and with <foreign lang="ar">ة</foreign>, is another pl.; (Th, S, Msb;) and is pl. of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28393-1" target="عَادٍ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n28397"/></foreign>, (K, TA,) which is <hi rend="ital">syn. with</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَدُوٌّ</foreign>; (S, K, TA;) as in the saying of a woman of the Arabs, <foreign lang="ar">أَشْمَتَ رَبُّ العَالَمِينَ عَادِيَكَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">May the Lord of the beings of the universe make thy enemy to rejoice at thy affliction</hi>]: (S, TA:) the fem. form of <foreign lang="ar">عَدُوٌّ</foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">عَدُوَّةٌ</foreign>, (S, Msb,) which is said by Az to be used when the meaning of an epithet is intended: (Msb:) it is said by ISk, (S, TA,) and in the “ Bari', ” (Msb,) that there is no instance of the measure <foreign lang="ar">فَعُولٌ</foreign> in the sense of <foreign lang="ar">فَاعِلٌ</foreign> but its fem. is without <foreign lang="ar">ة</foreign>, except <foreign lang="ar">عَدُوَّةٌ</foreign>, (S, Msb, K,) in the phrase <foreign lang="ar">هٰذِهِ عَدُوَّةٌ ٱللّٰهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">This</hi> woman <hi rend="ital">is the enemy of God</hi>]: accord. to Fr, <foreign lang="ar">عَدُوَّةٌ</foreign> has the affix <foreign lang="ar">ة</foreign> to assimilate it to <foreign lang="ar">صَدِيقَةٌ</foreign>; for a word is sometimes formed to accord with its contr.: (S, TA:) AZ says that he heard certain of the tribe of 'Okeyl say, [of some women,] <foreign lang="ar">هُنَّ وَلِيَّاتُ ٱللّٰهِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عَدُوَّاتُ ٱللّٰهِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أًوْلِيَاؤُهُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَاؤُهُ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">They are the friends of God</hi> and <hi rend="ital">the enemies of God</hi>]. (Msb.) [The pl.] <foreign lang="ar">عِدًى</foreign> signifies also <hi rend="ital">Persons distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remote, one from another:</hi> (ISd, K, TA:) and (K) <hi rend="ital">strangers,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">foreigners:</hi> (ISk, S, K, TA:) and <hi rend="ital">such as are distant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">remote, in respect of relationship;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">not relations:</hi> (TA:) as well as <hi rend="ital">enemies:</hi> (M, TA:) <foreign lang="ar">كَالأَعْدَآءِ</foreign>, which is added in the K after <foreign lang="ar">وَالغُرَبَآءُ</foreign>, should be <foreign lang="ar">وَالأَعْدَآءُ</foreign>. (TA.)    </entryFree>37:T1395,<entryFree id="n28397" key="عَادٍ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عَادٍ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [act. part. n. of <foreign lang="ar">عَدَا</foreign>, q. v.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  As such particularly signifying] <hi rend="ital">Acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyrannically; transgressing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">exceeding the proper limit:</hi> (Msb, TA:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">عَادُونَ</foreign>. (Msb.) Hence the saying, <foreign lang="ar">لَا أَشْمَتَ ٱللّٰهُ بِكَ عَادِيَكَ</foreign> i. e. [<hi rend="ital">May God not make to rejoice at thy affliction</hi>] <hi rend="ital">him who acts wrongfully to thee.</hi> (TA.) [And hence the phrase <foreign lang="ar">لِصٌّ عَادِى ظَهْرٍ</foreign>, expl. in art. <foreign lang="ar">ظهر</foreign>.] See also <foreign lang="ar">عَدَوَانٌ</foreign>. And see <foreign lang="ar">عَدُوٌّ</foreign>, with which it is syn.          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">Seizing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">carrying off, by force;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">snatching at unawares.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">العَادِى</foreign> signifies [particularly] <hi rend="ital">The lion;</hi> (K, TA;) because of his injuriousness, and his seizing men and making them his prey. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>    
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28397-1" target="عَدِىٌّ" n="1" type="1" subtype="SO" lang="ar" select="n28394"/></foreign> is a pl. of <foreign lang="ar">عَادٍ</foreign>, [or rather a quasi-pl. n.,] like as <foreign lang="ar">غَزِىٌّ</foreign> is of <foreign lang="ar">غَازٍ</foreign>; as such signifying <hi rend="ital">Runners upon their feet:</hi> (S, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">a company of men,</hi> (K, TA,) in the dial. of Hudheyl, (TA,) <hi rend="ital">that run to the fight</hi> (K, TA) and <hi rend="ital">the like:</hi> (TA:) or the <hi rend="ital">first, of the footmen,</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">foot-soldiers,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">that charge,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">assault;</hi> (K, TA;) because they run quickly: (TA:) like <foreign lang="ar">عَادِيَةٌ</foreign>, (K, TA,) of which the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">عَوَادٍ</foreign>, (TA,) in both senses: or this signifies the <hi rend="ital">horsemen;</hi> (K, TA;) i. e. the <hi rend="ital">first, of the horsemen, that charge,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">assault, in a hostile,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">predatory, incursion,</hi> especially; (TA;) or <hi rend="ital">horses making a hostile,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">predatory, incursion;</hi> and hence [the pl.] <foreign lang="ar">العَادِيَات</foreign> in the Kur c. 1. (TA in <pb n="1981"/> the supplement to this art.) And accord. to ElKhuwárezmee, <foreign lang="ar">عَدِىٌّ</foreign> particularly signifies The <hi rend="ital">foot-messengers of the sovereign,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">of the judge, who are made to run in quest of one against whom an accusation has been made, and to bring him, for the purpose of exacting from him the right,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">due, of his accuser.</hi> (De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., iii. 100.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَادِى العَوَادِى</foreign>, a phrase used by a poet, is expl. by IAar as meaning <hi rend="ital">The hardest,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">most pressing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">most severe, of occupations that turn one away,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">back, from a thing.</hi> (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">عَادٍ</foreign> and its fem. <foreign lang="ar">عَادِيَةٌ</foreign> voce <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوِىٌّ</foreign>.       <sense type="A" n="4">-A4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَادِيَا اللَّوْحِ</foreign> signifies <foreign lang="ar">طَرَفَاهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The two extremities,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">two sides, of the tablet</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the like</hi>]; (K, TA;) each of them being called <foreign lang="ar">عادى</foreign> [i. e. <foreign lang="ar">عَادِى اللَّوْحِ</foreign>, or a mistranscription for <foreign lang="ar">عَادٍ</foreign>], like <foreign lang="ar">عِدى</foreign> [i. e.   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28397-2" target="عِدًى" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n28380"/></foreign> or   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n28397-3" target="عَدًى" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n28378"/></foreign>, both mentioned above, voce <foreign lang="ar">عُدْوَةٌ</foreign>, as meaning, absolutely, <hi rend="ital">a side,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">lateral part</hi> or <hi rend="ital">portion</hi>]. (TA.)    </entryFree>38:T674,<entryFree id="n28398" key="عَادِيَةٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">عَادِيَةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [fem. of.<foreign lang="ar">عَادٍ</foreign>, q. v.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  As a subst., it signifies] <hi rend="ital">Wrongdoing, injustice, injuriousness,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyranny;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">evil,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mischief;</hi> (S, TA;) as in the saying <foreign lang="ar">دَفَعْتُ عَنْكَ عَادِيَةَ فُلَانٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I repelled,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">have repelled, from thee the wrongdoing</hi> &amp;c., and <hi rend="ital">the evil,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mischief, of such a one</hi>]: (S:) it is an inf. n. [or rather a quasi-inf. n.] like <foreign lang="ar">عَاقِبَةٌ</foreign>: and signifies also <hi rend="ital">sharpness,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hastiness, of temper;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">anger.</hi> (TA.) Also The <hi rend="ital">harm,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hurt,</hi> of poison. (Har p. 304.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">عُدَوَآءُ</foreign>, in three places.       <sense type="A" n="4">-A4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">عَوَادِى الكَرْمِ</foreign>, (K, TA,) of which <foreign lang="ar">عَادِيَةٌ</foreign> is the sing., (TA,) signifies <hi rend="ital">The grape-vines that are planted at the feet,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">roots, of great trees.</hi> (K, TA.)    </entryFree>39:T831,<entryFree id="n28399" key="أَعْدَى" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">أَعْدَى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees, and having several different significations]. <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَى مِنَ الجَرَبِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">More transitive,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">wont to pass from one to another, than the mange,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scab,</hi> is a prov. (Meyd.) And <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَى مِنَ الثُّؤَبَآءِ</foreign> is another prov., having a similar meaning [i. e. <hi rend="ital">More wont to pass from one to another,</hi> or, as we commonly say, <hi rend="ital">more catching, than yawning</hi>]; (Meyd;) for when a man yawns in the presence of others, they become affected as he is. (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">ثأب</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَى مِنَ الذِّئْبِ</foreign> is also a prov., and may mean <hi rend="ital">More wrongful,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">more inimical,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">more vehement in running, than the wolf.</hi> (Meyd.) <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَى مِنْ سُلَيْكٍ</foreign>, another prov., (expl. in the latter half of the first paragraph,) is from <foreign lang="ar">العَدْوُ</foreign>. (Meyd.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">هُوَ أَعْدَى شَىْءٍ</foreign> [app. meaning <hi rend="ital">It is the most effectual thing to aid,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">assist,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to avenge;</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَى</foreign> in this case being irregularly formed from the augmented verb in the phrase <foreign lang="ar">أَعْدَاهُ عَلَيْهِ</foreign>]. (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">ادو</foreign>: see <foreign lang="ar">آدَى</foreign> in that art.)    </entryFree>3a:T468,<entryFree id="n28400" key="تَعَادٍ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">تَعَادٍ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Uneven places,</hi> (K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">dissimilar in their several parts:</hi> occurring in this sense in a trad. (TA.) As mentions the saying <foreign lang="ar">مَكَانٍ <ref cref="n28400-1" target="مُتَعَادٍ" n="1" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n28404"/>نِمْتُ عَلَى</foreign>, meaning [<hi rend="ital">I slept upon</hi>] <hi rend="ital">a place dissimilar in its several parts; uneven:</hi> and <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ <ref cref="n28400-2" target="مُتَعَادِيَةٌ" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>هٰذِهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">This is land having in it burrows, and</hi> [<hi rend="ital">trenches,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">channels, such as are termed</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">لَخَاقِيق</foreign>. (S, TA.)    </entryFree>11:["$","$Lc",null,{"direction":"row","alignItems":"flex-start","width":"100%","background":"white","padding":{"base":"16px 8px","md":"24px 24px 32px
